title: Bombshell call for Kohli’s next move
text:
Indian view: Sunil Gavaskar has encouraged Virat Kohli to cheat to prove ICC’s double standards Staff writers, FOX SPORTS March 9, 2017 1:10pm 
INDIAN great Sunil Gavaskar has accused the International Cricket Council of double standards when dealing with Indian players as the fallout from the controversial second Test gets nasty. 
Gavaskar made his stand in the wake of the ICC’s decision not to officially reprimand Australian captain Steve Smith over his action to seek advice from teammates sitting in the dressing room after a day-four lbw dismissal. 
And he implored Indian skipper Virat Kohli to bring the issue to a head during the third Test in Ranchi, starting next Thursday, by repeating Smith’s breach of the rules. 
It is an extraordinary position to take for the man whose name graces the trophy for which the two teams are playing. 
“It can’t be that you have some countries get favourable treatment and some countries do not get favourable treatment,” Gavaskar told NDTV . 
“Whatever the breach of the code of conduct — and if there was no breach — tomorrow, for example, something similar is done by an Indian player, looking up at the dressing room, that is exactly the thing where I can identify the decision review system will be the Dressing Room Review System. 
“If an Indian player does that then he also should not be pulled up at all. That is where we will see. 
“I would actually love to see Virat Kohli, if he is given out, he looks at the Indian dressing room, gets some sort of feedback from them — yes or no, I don’t know what signal they decide upon — and then let’s see what the match referee and the ICC decides then.”

The Indian team and its management remain furious at the inaction by the ICC over Smith’s indiscretion — for which he apologised post-match and admitted was a “brain fade”. 
But that acceptance of guilt is unsatisfactory in the eyes of Gavaskar, who described the actions of the ICC and match referee Chris Broad as an affront to the BCCI, Kohli and the Indian team. 
“You and I know exactly what the match referee should have done and it appears that he hasn’t,” Gavakar said. 
“He hasn’t seen that there is anything done that was in breach of the ICC code of conduct. 
“So you and I can rave and rant and do whatever we have to do about it, but the match referee says nothing’s the matter — or at least that’s what the ICC statement suggests. 
“You can say it’s wrong, it’s not correct, it’s a snub to the BCCI and Virat Kohli and the Indian team, but basically that is that.” media_camera Sunil Gavaskar and Allan Border with the trophy that bears their name 
Former Indian opening batsman Aakash Chopra described the whole situation as “a complete miscarriage of justice”. 
“Personally, in my humble opinion, this should have been reprimanded,” he said. 
“There must have been some ramifications because what we saw was caught on tape. 
“(Australia) did abuse the rule and they got (away) scot-free which is slightly disappointing.”
